senses.de: To believe in yourself or someone else, to trust in their ability
senses.ex: I have confidence in your ability to complete the project on time.

Tips.title: Inner Strength
Tips.description: Confidence here implies having inner strength and positive feelings about abilities or decisions.
Tips.example: Despite the criticism, her confidence remained unshaken.

Tips.title: Supporting Others
Tips.description: To show confidence in people means you are supportive and believe in their capacities.
Tips.example: The teacher's confidence in his students inspired them to succeed.

Tips.title: Not Arrogance
Tips.description: 'Confidence' should not be confused with arrogance; it's about belief without disparaging others.
Tips.example: His confidence inspired his team, unlike arrogance which could have pushed them away.

senses.de: Information only shared between certain people and not meant to be told to others
senses.ex: She told me her plans in strict confidence, so I can't tell anyone else.

Tips.title: Privacy Expected
Tips.description: This confidence signals something told privately and should be kept secret.
Tips.example: My friend discussed her fears with me in confidence.

Tips.title: Trust Implications
Tips.description: Revealing private information indicates high trust; breaking it can harm relationships.
Tips.example: He broke my confidence when he shared my personal problems with others.

senses.de: An act of trust or reliance
senses.ex: His lending of the car was a huge vote of confidence in me.

Tips.title: Reflects Reliability
Tips.description: 'Confidence' here reflects trust in someone's reliability based on positive past experiences.
Tips.example: Lending her the vintage car was a sign of confidence in her driving.

senses.de: A feeling of certainty or assurance about something
senses.ex: They expressed confidence that the issue would be resolved soon.

Tips.title: Expect Positive Outcome
Tips.description: Expressing confidence often indicates an expected positive outcome or success in something.
Tips.example: The team has confidence they'll win the championship.

Tips.title: Context Matters
Tips.description: The setting can determine whether expressing confidence is seen as positive or presumptuous.
Tips.example: In the interview, she exuded just the right amount of confidence.

senses.de: A scheme to trick someone out of their money or valuables
senses.ex: He was arrested for running a confidence trick on elderly people.

Tips.title: Deceptive Intention
Tips.description: In legal contexts, confidence refers to dishonest acts intended to deceive people.
Tips.example: The con artist's confidence trick conned many into investing in fake stocks.

Tips.title: Cautious of Strangers
Tips.description: Be wary of unsolicited offers of 'easy money' as they might be confidence tricks.
Tips.example: Always research before investing to avoid falling for a confidence trick.

Assurance.wordDefinition:
Assurance is a stronger word than confidence. It means having a guarantee or a promise that something will definitely happen or be provided.

For example, if you have assurance that you will get a job if you pass a test, then you can be confident that you will get the job if you pass the test.

So assurance is about having a promise or a guarantee that something will happen, while confidence is about having trust in your own abilities.

Belief.wordDefinition:
Belief refers to an acceptance of something as true, often based on faith or personal conviction. Confidence pertains to the trust or assurance in oneself or others in the ability to achieve a task or goal.

For example, you might have a belief in a higher power, but not necessarily the confidence to speak in public. Alternatively, you might have confidence in your athletic abilities, but not necessarily a belief in luck.

Belief is often subjective and personal, whereas confidence can be more objective and measurable. Both words are applicable in a wide range of contexts, from religious beliefs to confidence in a business plan.

Bold.wordDefinition:
Boldness refers to a willingness to take risks and act in a daring or fearless manner. It is applicable in situations where one needs to do something outside of their comfort zone, such as making a bold move in a game or standing up for what they believe in.

In summary, boldness is about taking action, while confidence is about how one carries themselves in that action.

Certainty.wordDefinition:
Certainty refers to the state of being completely sure or confident about something without any doubt or hesitation. It is applicable when there is complete evidence, proof, or knowledge about a situation or issue.

Confidence refers to a feeling of trust or belief in oneself, abilities, or someone/something else, even though there may be some uncertainty or doubt.

It is applicable when there is some level of uncertainty or risk involved. For example, I am confident that I will do well in my exams, even though I am not completely sure.

Conviction.wordDefinition:
Conviction refers to a strong belief or opinion. It's the feeling of being certain that something is true or right.

Both confidence and conviction are important in different contexts. Confidence is applicable in situations that require personal competence or skill, such as public speaking or taking a test.

Conviction is applicable in situations that require strong beliefs or principles, such as standing up for what you believe in or making a moral decision.

Courage.wordDefinition:
Courage is the ability to face and overcome fear, danger, and uncertainty. It is the willingness to take risks and act in the face of adversity, even when one does not feel confident.

Courage is applicable in situations where one is facing unknown or challenging circumstances, and requires strength and determination to persevere.

Confidence is about having faith in oneself, while courage is about rising to the occasion even when one is unsure or afraid.

Faith.wordDefinition:
Confidence refers to a feeling of trust and assurance in oneself or one's abilities, while faith refers to a belief in something without tangible evidence.

Confidence is mostly applicable in situations where one's own skills and abilities are required, such as in sports or exams, while faith is more applicable in matters of religion or spirituality.

Confidence is based on personal experience and knowledge, while faith is often based on religious teachings or spiritual beliefs.

Trust.wordDefinition:
Trust refers to a person's belief in the reliability, honesty and integrity of another person or thing. For example, if someone trusts their friend, it means they believe their friend will keep their promises and not betray their trust.

Trust is applicable when referring to other people or things.

For example, a person may have confidence in their ability to pass a test, but they need to trust that their teacher will grade them fairly.

A person may have confidence in their driving skills, but they need to trust that other drivers will follow the rules of the road.

quotes.Text: Since the team understands that the leader is de facto in charge, in that respect, a leader has nothing to prove. But in another respect, a leader has everything to prove: Every member of the team must develop the trust and confidence that their leader will exercise good judgment, remain calm, and make the right decisions when it matters most.
quotes.Title: American
quotes.Name: Jocko Willink

quotes.Text: You gain strength, courage, and confidence by every experience in which you really stop to look fear in the face. You are able to say to yourself, 'I lived through this horror. I can take the next thing that comes along.
quotes.Title: American First Lady
quotes.Name: Eleanor Roosevelt

quotes.Text: I feel that confidence in women - especially young girls of color - but women, in general, is so important. It is so important for us to arm ourselves and become powerful at a very young age.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Viola Davis

quotes.Text: If my parents were still alive, they would be very proud. They gave me a good start in life, the values that have driven me, and the confidence to believe in myself.
quotes.Title: Scottish Coach
quotes.Name: Alex Ferguson

quotes.Text: I always thought that I was an important musician. If you don't have that confidence, why would you go on and do it?
quotes.Title: American Artist
quotes.Name: Yoko Ono

quotes.Text: Kindness in words creates confidence. Kindness in thinking creates profoundness. Kindness in giving creates love.
quotes.Title: Chinese Philosopher
quotes.Name: Lao Tzu

quotes.Text: I didn't have any confidence in my beauty when I was young. I felt like a character actress, and I still do.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Meryl Streep

quotes.Text: It is not so much our friends' help that helps us, as the confidence of their help.
quotes.Title: Greek Philosopher
quotes.Name: Epicurus

quotes.Text: If you have no confidence in self, you are twice defeated in the race of life.
quotes.Title: Jamaican Publisher
quotes.Name: Marcus Garvey

quotes.Text: Courage is a mean with regard to fear and confidence.
quotes.Title: Greek Philosopher
quotes.Name: Aristotle
